meanings.def: (in the UK) a man of high rank in the nobility (= people of high social class), or somebody who has been given the title ‘lord’ as an honour
examples: She's married to a lord.
The head of the successful construction group became a lord in 1984.
They entered a huge hall filled with lords and ladies.

meanings.def: (in the UK) the title used by a lord
examples: Lord Beaverbrook
He was made a peer and took the title Lord Northcliffe.

meanings.def: a title used for some high official positions in the UK
examples: the Lord Chancellor
the Lord Mayor
Lord Justice Slade

meanings.def: (in the UK) a title of respect used when speaking to a judge, bishop or some male members of the nobility (= people of high social class)
a powerful man in medieval Europe, who owned a lot of land and property
examples: a feudal lord
the lord of the manor

meanings.def: a title used to refer to God or Christ
examples: Love the Lord with all your heart.

meanings.def: a title used to refer to Christ
(in the UK) the part of Parliament whose members are not elected by the people of the country
examples: The Lords has/have not yet reached a decision.

meanings.def: the building where members of the House of Lords meet
very drunk
used to show that you are surprised, annoyed or worried about something
examples: Good Lord, what have you done to your hair!

meanings.def: used to emphasize what you are saying
examples: Lord knows, I tried to teach her.

meanings.def: used to say that you do not know the answer to something
examples: ‘Why did she say that?’ ‘Lord knows!’

meanings.def: any particular year after the birth of Christ

idioms.def: used to show that you are surprised, annoyed or worried about something
examples: Good Lord, what have you done to your hair!

idioms.def: used to emphasize what you are saying
examples: Lord knows, I tried to teach her.

idioms.def: used to say that you do not know the answer to something
examples: ‘Why did she say that?’ ‘Lord knows!’

idioms.idiom: year of grace | year of our Lord
idioms.def: any particular year after the birth of Christ

meanings.def: to act as if you are better or more important than somebody
examples: A good manager does not try to lord it over his or her team.

idioms.def: to act as if you are better or more important than somebody
examples: A good manager does not try to lord it over his or her team.

meanings.def: born Frederick Edwin Smith (1872-1930) a British lawyer and conservative politician who was well known for the humorous things he said. He was Attorney General (1915-18) and then Lord Chancellor (1919-22), when he improved the laws of land and property.

William Cecil (1520-98) a British politician. He was one of the most important members of Queen Elizabeth I's government, working as Secretary of State (1558-72) and lord treasurer (1572-98). He was responsible for making England a strong military and economic power. He was also responsible for many grand buildings, including Burghley House. He was made a knight in 1551 and a baron in 1571.

George Gordon Byron (1788-1824) an English poet whose life is as well known as his poetry. He had love affairs with many women, including Lady Caroline Lamb, and probably had a child by his half-sister (= sister by a different mother). He was a leading figure in the Romantic Movement and himself lived the life of a romantic hero, often unhappy about a love affair and angry about the unfair political and social situations he saw around him. His work, including Childe Harold's Pilgrimage (1812-18) and Don Juan (1818-20), often expresses the same feelings. Rejected by British society, he spent much of his life abroad and died helping the Greeks in their struggle against Turkish rule.“Mad, bad and dangerous to know.”Lady Caroline Lamb's description of Byron
James Brudenell (1797-1868) a British army officer, well known for leading the Charge of the Light Brigade during the Crimean War

born Robert Stewart (1769-1822) a British Tory politician who was responsible for the Act of Union with Ireland (1800). In 1809 he fought a duel (= a fight with guns to settle a quarrel) with his rival, Canning, and left the government. He returned as Foreign Secretary (1812-22). After the Napoleonic Wars he tried to keep the balance of power between European states.

George Nathaniel Curzon (1859-1925) a British diplomat (= person who represents their country abroad) and politician. He became Viceroy of India at the age of only 39. Later (1919-24) he was Foreign Secretary. Curzon had a strong personality and many people thought he was too proud. There was a popular rhyme about him: “My name is George Nathaniel Curzon,I am a most superior person.”

Henry Stuart (1545-67) the second husband of Mary, Queen of Scots, and the father of King James I of England (James VI of Scotland). Darnley is best known for his murder of Mary's secretary, David Rizzio, in 1566. Darnley was himself murdered the following year, probably by the Earl of Bothwell, who then took Darnley's place as Mary's third husband.
born George Lascelles (1923-2011) an English earl who was a cousin of Queen Elizabeth II. For much of his life he was closely involved with music, especially opera, in Britain.
